history.content: I don't think you're allowed to retake a course unless you got worse than a C a D+ or worse in (https://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades). But all the material is posted online anyways so you're not really missing out on anything, plus you can still audit lectures.

I don't think you're allowed to retake a course unless you got worse than a C a D- or worse in (https://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades). But all the material is posted online anyways so you're not really missing out on anything, plus you can still audit lectures.

I don't think you're allowed to retake a course unless you got worse than a C worse than a D+ in (https://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades). But all the material is posted online anyways so you're not really missing out on anything, plus you can still audit lectures.

I don't think you're allowed to retake a course unless you got worse than a C better than a D+ in (https://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades). But all the material is posted online anyways so you're not really missing out on anything, plus you can still audit lectures.

I don't think you're allowed to retake a course unless you got worse than a C (https://registrar.berkeley.edu/academic-records/grades). But all the material is posted online anyways so you're not really missing out on anything, plus you can still audit lectures.

children.subject: But if he or she doesn't remember many things, doesn't that increase the risk that a student will be taught with a mistake and not realize that it's wrong? It seems like it might do more harm than good.

Maybe consider lab assisting or teaching the course (through CSM or CS 370)? Teaching a concept helps you understand it much better. Plus, you can go on to teach other classes and solidify your learning there, or later apply to be on course staff and learn even more.

history.content:
I find myself forgetful about a lot of the things learned in 61B, and would potentially like to "retake" the course so I get a much better fundamentals in data structures (would be P/NP for no credit). I would like to redo some of the projects as well (again, for knowledge/better fundamentals).

What is the best way to go about doing this? Should I just audit the class? Or just enroll in it? I've never done something like this before, so any advice would be great. Thank you.
history.subject: Retaking CS 61B for the knowledge?
